body.p: Article: The Role of Sonography in Renal Artery Stenosis Evaluation and Stent Placement
Objectives: After studying the article entitled “The Role of Sonography in Renal Artery Stenosis Evaluation and Stent Placement,” you will be able to:

list-item.p: Use appropriate duplex sonography parameters to diagnose significant renal artery stenosis
Explain the relative merits of different imaging techniques for renal artery stenosis
Determine a patient’s risk factors for developing renal artery stenosis

Renal artery stenosis secondary to atherosclerotic disease is most likely to be located in the
Proximal renal artery
Mid-renal artery
Distal renal artery
Renal hilum

A hemodynamically significant renal artery stenosis is defined as
Any atherosclerotic narrowing
A greater than 50% diameter reduction
One causing a measurable pressure drop, likely greater than 60% to 70% diameter narrowing
One involving the entire length of the renal artery

Renal artery stenosis disease progression within five years is seen in approximately
20% of patients
50% of patients
75% of patients
90% of patients

Common risk factors for renal artery stenosis include all the following except
Age
Female sex
Diabetes
Tobacco use

A commonly used criterion for renal artery stenosis greater than 60% diameter reduction is a renal-aortic ratio (RAR) greater than
2.5
3.0
3.5
4.0

An indirect criterion for proximal renal artery stenosis is an acceleration time measured at the hilum of the kidney of
0.70 seconds
0.35 seconds
0.15 seconds
0.07 seconds

A criticism of magnetic resonance angiography for determining renal artery stenosis is a possibility of overestimating disease in approximately
15% of patients
20% of patients
30% of patients
40% of patients

Compared with angiography, computed tomographic angiography is reported to have a sensitivity for detection of renal artery stenosis of approximately
60% to 65%
70% to 75%
80% to 85%
90% to 95%

The sensitivity of technically adequate duplex sonography for the detection of renal artery stenosis has been recently reported to be as high as approximately
85%
90%
95%
99%

The current procedure of choice to treat renal artery stenosis is
Percutaneous balloon angioplasty with stenting
Laparoscopic endarterectomy
Endovascular renal artery bypass
Open surgical bypass
